titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 10. V:45. Bath with Antoine Swam 1. hour— Mann with a Letter from J. Bailey. Frye— At the Office. Selden with Pollard and Brown. Gave them a certified extract from Records of Florida Treaty Claim Commissioners— Cabinet Meeting— Calhoun and Wirt present. Anderson Comptroller— Contingent fund H.R.U.S. deficient 15000. dollars— Power of P.U.S. to transfer from the appropriation for members pay— Letter from Genl. La Fayette—coming to U.S—whether in public or private vessel— Colombian Privateer Santander—her Piratical aggressions. Remonstrances to be made— Whether orders to be given to take her? R. W. Meade’s Letters and Protest my answer approved— Wirt’s remarks. Meeting adjourned till to-morrow Noon— Walk with Johnson Hellen at eve. Act of Congress concerning Florida wreckers, not signed— Discussion if it can now be signed— Conclusion that it shall not.

11. VI. Swam with Antoine to Bridge 1 1/2 hour— W. Lee and Curtis to be Consul at Tampico— Carbery to be fourth Auditor. Cabinet Meeting. Calhoun & Wirt. Is the unsigned Act Law? Wirt says no— Privateer Santander. Orders to be given to Porter to take her—for the robbery— Other grounds— Officers, Citizens U.S— Acts of Congress 3. Watkins 4th. Auditor. Van Ness’s Commission. Ship to be sent for La Fayette— Political consequences. his views— Brest, Havre, Marseilles— Southard to return from Norfolk to-morrow— At the Office H. Preble. Failure of his document, from Spain and of his claim— James, and Lytle, quakers, with Howland— claim on G.B. for captures in 1805 and 1807. desperate— Rowlett with Tanner’s Atlas’s— J. S. Barbour. Hodgson and Wyer. Evening walk with Johnson Hellen to Frye’s— Mrs Bingham there— Letter to C.F.A.

12. VI. At the Office. Halsey, for Agnew, in the Porto-Rico affair—complaint against C. L. Parker, Consul at Curacao. Stackelberg with a Letter and papers—to draw bills for £1000— Burrows—upon two cases—one of a vessel seized; and the other of a vessel sold, without transfer of Register L. Cheves—for R. W. Meade— I had written to him and sent him a copy of the decision of Commissioners— No opinion delivered— Old claim of a Mr Hamilton of S.C. Slave Commission will disagree, about average value— Jeremy Robinson. His papers and claim for Salary or compensation— Asked him to make it in writing— At P.U.S— Anderson, Southard and Wirt there— Transfer of appropriation—fund of H.R.U.S. Power of P.U.S— by Law— Wirt and Southard ay. mine nay. Privateer Santander— Colombian Prize Ordinance— Letter from C. J. Ingersoll. Despatch from H. Nelson. To send for Salazar— Gave Hodgson the Ordinance to translate— Wyer here after dinner— Evening walk with J. Hellen. Refusal of N. Edwards to answer— Calhoun.

13. VI:30. Johnson Hellen, departed— Heard Little. Acts 17.19.20. Second Anniversary, since the opening of the Church— J. W. Taylor there. Lodges at his brother’s— Stopped there— Conversation with him— Proceedings of investigating Committee— Edwards examined— His reply— Noble’s testimony strong against him— Cheves in favour of Crawford. Benton’s remark upon Barbour’s speaking to Cook— Bias of Floyd, Webster and M’Arthur— Stranger at Baker’s. Romans 12.12. At eve Little 1. Peter 2.15.16— Walk home with Southard— His visit to Norfolk and Richmond— despatches from Stewart.

14. VI:30. Letters from my wife— Cabinet Meeting at Noon. Calhoun. Southard and Wirt present. Colombian privateer Santander. P.U.S. read a Draft of a Declaration or Proclamation—merely for consideration to make known our principles— Wirt’s objections— Colombia not bound, by our Treaty with Spain that free ships make free goods. Colombian privateering ordinance authorises foreigners to privateer in their service and authorises taking enemy’s property out of neutral ships. Chase therefore cannot be taken— Right of expatriation? Decision of Supreme Court. Calhoun doubts all right of expatriation— Our naturalization Law assumes it— P.U.S. remarks our political position towards Europe and America. conclusion to discuss and not to take— But threaten to take, by an Article in National Intelligencer!— No! No!— La Fayette to be informed that a ship will be sent for him, whenever he can fix the time— Watkins at the Office— Florida Commissioners withhold all their opinions. complaints of Dias and R. W. Meade— Baltimore fantasies— After dinner Webster here, with Dr Osgood from the Havana.

15. VI.Taylor of Alexandria—a disappointed claimant under the Florida Treaty Commission— Asks for his documents. I cannot give them—for copies, perhaps— Genl. Macomb with Lieutt Whiting— Mr Agg, with application of Espada, Commercial Agent at Campeachy, for Consulate of Tampico— At the Office Halsey, for Agnew, and Instructions to C. L. Parker, the Consul at Curacao— Bulfinch with young Coolidge returned from Mr Jefferson’s and Mr Madison’s— Tingey; lamenting the removal of Jos. Wingate as Collector at Bath; and seeking for a remedy. Mr M’Lean the Postmaster General, to enquire of some of my votes on the Louisiana Government Law in 1804: about the importation of Slaves— He thinks Clay will not get the vote of Ohio— Burrows came for a Letter to Salazar, that I had promised him— I wrote and sent it— Case of a Vessel Seized and bonded at Carthagena. Watkins with a Letter asking for documents I cannot give. a young man named Smith of Georgetown renewing
an application for a Clerkship in the Department— Draft despatch to R. C. Anderson. Sent to P.U.S— After dinner judge Thruston called, and took up his note— Walking met Jeremiah Nelson— Returning home found E. Livingston at my door— Recommends Hepburn— Lieutt. Sherburne came, and I desired he would call to-morrow Morning.

16. VI.Sherburne here, with a Book on Elocution by Dr. Barber, a pupil of Thelwall. His wishes to get Hassler employed; by dismissing the seven navy Chaplain’s—all but one intemperate— At the Office. Richard for Letter to Witherell— Bad prospect of his cause. Woodward’s opinion. Jeremy Robinson; came for a decision upon his applications for compensation and for employment— Nelson of Massachusetts came to take leave; going tomorrow. Twice at P.U.S— Undecided with regard to Robinson—but thinks he can neither allow him any thing, nor employ him. Walk alone after dinner. Eve at Dr Thornton’s.

17. VI. Note from N. Edwards, enquiring of the day, when he was nominated for the Mission to Mexico— Answered— At the Office— Southard, of W. F. Steele. His proposal to exchange the Office of District Attorney for West, to that for East-Florida. Letter from Steele— Allegations against him—flaw in his defence. Case of Angus; who has been dismissed from the Service— Paragraph in New York paper, and this day’s Intelligencer— Southard has a Letter from Angus’s wife— And from Genl. Swift— Hodgson—brought back the Colombian Prize Ordinance— Had been examined before the investigating Committee, this Morning; to invalidate the testimony of Noble— Cross questioned about his connection with the Department of State. Torrens to take leave— Going to Philadelphia, to wait some weeks for the late-appointed Minister from Mexico—Musquiz— If he does not come; Torrens will go Northward, to Saratoga and Boston, and return here in November— Dr Watkins; who answered Letters from Dias and Dumas, asking for the decisions on their claims before the Florida Treaty Commissioners. At P.U.S. Took to him Letter from W. P. Van Ness—declining appointment of fourth Auditor. Whom to appoint—Watkins, Slade, or one of many others— Resolutions of a Meeting at Bath, in favour of Wingate— E. Livingston with P.U.S. when I went in— Withdrew— P.U.S. spoke of the proceedings of the Committee— I had heard little of them since Sunday— Rumours of Benton’s Pistol purchase— And of a duel in perspective between Forsyth and Cook— After dinner call at King the Painter’s— Met Mrs Talbot and Forrest’s— Solitary walk— J. W. Taylor—dispositions of the Committee. Webster’s eagerness to censure Edwards— Noble’s testimony against him. Taylors objection to censure, the house not being in Session to correct the report of the Committee if wrong— One of two views to be taken—to state Edwards by facts to be the aggressor, or directly to pronounce the charges frivolous and malignant.

18. VI:45.T. Law called, to speak of the Chamber in the Capitol, assigned to the Columbian Institute— Asked me to deliver an Address at entering upon it— I have not time— He says M’Lane carried away a Letter from Crawford to him— He is going to England, perhaps. W. Elliot—applied for employment for Mr Little, to record the Patents. Benton, Senator from Missouri called to take leave— At the Office. Hodgson— Went to the Committee to day; to say Mr Crawford had promised him employment— G. Graham, to enquire about the Florida Land title Commissions— The Reports to be examined— Richard, Delegate from Michigan to take leave— Gave him a Letter to Govr Cass— Opinion of D. Webster, E. Livingston and J. W. Taylor on his suit in Court— Watkins— Gave him his Commission as 4th. Auditor. My Son John returned from Bedford— Evening walk alone.

19. VI:45.Thornton here— Talk about weights and measures. Captain Sherrington, with Letters from S. Smith and Jacob Adams. Case of the Ship Numa rundown by a French Frigate— He is going to France—Gave him a Letter for Mr Brown— Jonathan Barber, about his book upon elocution— Thinks it a new discovery.— Wishes for my opinion. Calhoun—read me a Letter to the Committee of Investigation; and one to D. Webster that he had written; stating the fact that N. Edwards had sent through him to D. P. Cook the packet from Wheeling containing his Address to the House; but stating that he had no other knowledge of it, and offering to give any information to the Committee that they might desire— He said that he had read the draft of these Letters this Morning to P.U.S. who at first thought it would be proper to send them— But Mr Southard and Mr Wirt afterwards coming in, it had been thought on reflection that it would have the appearance of volunteering testimony— And that Edwards had lost himself, and would certainly sink under this affair, so that interference now might connect unnecessarily the administration with the Odium which would be attached to him— That the effort of Mr Crawford’s agents now was to fix upon the President and other members of the Administration, a combination and concert with Edwards to attack Crawford; while the fact was directly the reverse, and Crawford’s career had been an uninterrupted series of Attacks upon the Administration always disavowed or disguised by himself— That in this state of things the cause of the Administration should be kept as distinct as possible from that of Edwards—and when the issue is made with Crawford, it should be on independent ground— To this Calhoun yielded, but brought the Letters to me, to consult me upon them— I said I should not oppose my opinion to those of the President, Mr Southard, and Mr Wirt— But I believed it would ultimately be impossible to avoid the
issue, and inclined to think it would be as well to take it now, as at any time— I had observed in the newspapers statements that Cook and Edwards had declined answering the question through whom the packet had been transmitted, and intimations that it had gone through the war Office— But there was another occasion on which his Calhoun’s name had been mentioned by Noble; in relating his conversation with Edwards; and upon a call from Edwards to tell all the Conversation, he had stated that Edwards told him he had long expected this Mexican Appointment— That the President was in his power through the means of Coll. Lane; and that Mr Calhoun—here the witness was stopped by Mr Livingston, and Mr Forsyth had agreed that it was not relevant— Now this stopping of the testimony would operate worse on the public mind, than if every thing had come out. And come out it all ultimately must— Calhoun said he believed so too; but that it should be by the Presidents acting directly upon Crawford— It was impossible for an Administration in this Country to get along with one of its Members in secret and perpetual hostility against it— This had been the case with Crawford from 1816 down to this day— And what had been for the last nine Months the situation of the Treasury— No Secretary but Asbury Dickins; scarcely any papers signed by Mr Crawford, and a facsimile, engraved, and his daughters hand, used even for most of these— I asked if these were facts— They were said to be— Did the President know, what the real management at the Treasury was—he believed not— Had the President any distrust of Mr Crawford? He believed he had now—from what he had said this Morning— I said the President had never intimated to me the slightest distrust of Crawford— And I had never hinted a sentiment of distrust of him to the President— In the case of L. Harris had sworn to the thing that was not; but I attributed it altogether to an error of Memory. I had two years ago, but to the President certain questions in writing which he had promised me he would answer in writing; but had not yet done so— As the material fact was of the day, when a thing was said, I was afraid that his own memory would not serve him to speak precisely— But he would not, for he could not sustain the assertion of Crawford— I had done every thing that man could honestly do, to keep on terms with him— But I expected it would ultimately not be possible— He asked if the President could not now remove him— I said no— He could not, because though for years he had been giving ample cause for it, there was yet nothing new, upon which a case could be made out— Much more conversation to this effect— Southard came in— Hornet and Ontario, ready to go to Sea— At the Office— Jeremy Robinson, his story and his tears— I promised to look over his case again— Wyer— At P.U.S. with Note of W. T. Bourne, and Letter of Jeremy Robinson— Mr Yard at P.U.S and James Monroe. Evening Solitary walk.

20. VI:30. Heard Little. Psalm 131.1. And 1. Corinthians 13.8.9.10. No church at Baker’s— N. Edwards at Church, and took a Seat with me— Has a sepulchral cough— Met D. P. Cook, who walked home with me— Committee have closed their Examinations— Edwards proposed last Night, and repeated the proposal this Morning, that Crawford should be examined— Noble’s testimony— Cook says Edwards explicitly denies the encomium upon Crawford attested by Noble— I said if it was not true, he ought to meet it by most explicit denial to the Committee— He says also that O’Neal had told General Jackson that a Clerk in the Treasury had told him Mr Crawford had received Stevenson’s Letter in 1819. That Jackson told it to Eaton, by whom Edwards was informed of it. Cook has seen O’Neal who confirms this statement, and says that since the publication of Stephenson’s Letter, he took it to the person; who read it; and said that was the Letter— But he would upon no earthly consideration consent to be summoned to testify to the fact— And O’Neal was equally unwilling to be examined; and objected that it would implicate General Jackson— Upon which Cook said Edwards had concluded rather to lose the benefit of the testimony than to involve Jackson— He said there was nothing to affect Edwards’s credit except Noble’s testimony, and if the Committee should report against Edwards, he thought he would resign, and make his final appeal to Congress at their next Session.

21. VI:45. Note from P.U.S. Cabinet Meeting at 1/2 past nine. Report of the Committee of investigation, with all the documents, brought about Noon, by Webster, and Clarke Clerk of H.R. to P.U.S. Calhoun, Southard and Wirt present— Papers read— Report of the Committee— Edwards— Reply to Crawford’s answer— His argument on the Evidence— Forsyth’s remarks— Depositions of Noble, J. Mason, Elkins, Wharton, Seaton and Dickins— Much discussion upon what is to be done. P.U.S. read a draft of a notification to Edwards of the revocation of his Commission as Minister to Mexico. I questioned upon what assignable motive this step could be taken— The Committee have passed no censure upon him— But it is apprehended that Noble’s testimony of his having denied that he was the author of the A. B. publications, and pronounced a panegyric upon Mr Crawford, while the nomination to the Mexican Mission was before the Senate, will blast his character before the Nation, and the President thinks that if he does not remove him, his own character will be blasted too. Calhoun said that every one of Edwards’s charges against Mr Crawford was substantiated; but still thought that he must be removed, unless he should resign— Mr Wirt and Mr Southard
concurred in this opinion— Mine was that Mr Edwards for his own sake, and in justice to his own character ought to resign, but that this act ought to be entirely voluntary on his part, and if he should not resign, there was nothing in the report of the Committee, or in the proceedings of the House, or in the Documents, which would justify the President in removing him— Much warm and animated discussion upon this point. In supporting with the most consciencious earnestness my own sentiment, I avowed the determination to acquiesce in the decision of the President— It was thought advisable to ascertain what were Mr Edwards’s own intentions, and Mr Wirt as his particular and intimate friend was requested to see and converse with Mr Cook to this end— I was earnestly desirous that this consultation should be confined merely to the enquiry what Mr Edwards proposed to do, without intimating to him even a wish on the part of the Executive that he would resign— The subject assumed a range of discussion involving the whole conduct of the Administration, from its commencement— The invaried hostile position of all Mr Crawford’s partizans to the Administration, and his own ambiguous conduct, always disavowing, yet never controuling the opposition of his friends, were freely noticed— The President read parts of a Letter from Crawford to him of 4. July 1822. of his answer, written in August, and of a reply from Crawford in September or October all originating in a Letter from A. Scott then at Pensacola to Crawford, mentioning a rumour there, that he was to be removed. This correspondence was a partial clearing up of clouds and suspicions—and terminated in the expression of the President’s wish that Crawford should continue in the Administration— He disavowed any intentional opposition, explained some oppositions of opinion; and intimated suspicions that from two quarters prejudices against him had been excited in the President’s mind; which the President in reply pointedly denies— As the President omitted the reading of most of those parts of the Letter, I asked him if I was one of the persons alluded to; which he declined answering— The state of the Treasury for the last nine Months was adverted to; and the question asked whether the President knew what it was— He knew only generally from the Reports of the Comptroller Anderson, that all was correctly transacted; but rumours are in circulation, concerning which the President declared his determination to enquire further— The meeting lasted till near 7. in the Evening, and was adjourned till 8 to-morrow Morning. After dinner, I called to see J. W. Taylor, who goes early to-morrow for home. He mentioned to me many particulars of the proceedings of the Committee. Floyd the Chairman offered a Resolution declaring the charges of Edwards
frivolous and malicious— This no other member of the Committee supported, but Webster unceasingly laboured to get a sentiment inserted into the Report to the same effect. This was resisted by Taylor who was supported by Livingston, and resulted in a compromise greatly moderating the proposed panegyric of Webster upon the management of the Treasury by Mr Crawford, and forbearing all expression of Sentiment against Edwards— From Webster’s conduct in the Committee, Taylor has no doubt that he is a thorough-going political partizan of Mr Crawford, and he connects with it his late visit to Buchanan in Pennsylvania— His persuading Noble who had already reached Pennsylvania on his way home to come back and testify against Edwards, and other movements in concert with other persons— Taylor had seen M’Lean, who he said was alarmed at this new and extensive federal organization for Crawford; and told him he had information that the Electoral Law, would not pass in New-York. He referred also to a Letter in the Richmond Enquirer, composing in substance an Administration for Crawford of Van Buren, Forsyth, Webster and M’Lane; and a corresponding article in praise of Buchanan in Binns’s paper at Philadelphia— M’Lean’s conclusion was of the absolute necessity, that Jackson should be given up all who mean to oppose the election of Crawford— Taylor told me he might probably see Clinton at New-York, and asked if he should converse with him as had been heretofore proposed— I said yes; but advised him to say nothing that would either import reliance upon Clinton, or expectation of support from him—with this he fully concurred.

22. VI:15. Cabinet Meeting from 8. A.M. till 1/2 past nine in the Evening; with the interval of about an hour to dine, which we did at the President’s. Present, Calhoun, Southard and Wirt— Mr Wirt mentioned that he had seen and conversed last Evening and this morning with Mr Cook; that in the course of the day, Mr Edwards would send in his resignation, or give notice that he should expect an intimation from the President to that effect. I then observed that I remained of the same opinion that I had entertained from the beginning of this Affair— That for his own sake, for the support of his own character, and to take away all colour of surmise that the President, or any member of his Administration was in concert with him in his controversy with Mr Crawford, he ought to resign his Office— But that if he should not perform this act voluntarily, I was of opinion, not only that he ought not to be removed; but that no Intimation should be given him of a wish on the part of the Executive that he should resign— That he should be ordered to proceed immediately to Mexico; with a reservation that if at the next Session of Congress, the House, should
adopt any measure requiring his presence, he should be prepared to expect his recall, and to return at the shortest notice to the United States so as to be here in the course of the Session— I assigned at large my reasons for this opinion, which was that there was nothing in the course of proceedings; either of the House or of the Committee that would warrant his removal. So far as the report of the Committee went to palliate, to excuse and to justify Mr Crawford, I had no objection to make to it— That there was in the Committee partiality to Mr Crawford was certain, and the motives for it were easily seen— A prevailing popular clamour against Edwards, and personal impulses of interest and ambition in the breast of Mr Webster, to catch the prospect of advancement in the Event of Crawford’s election. Yet with all this partiality the Committee had not expressed a sentiment of the slightest censure upon Edwards— Though Webster had caused a secret and most improper intimation to be given to the President that the Committee would censure Edwards; though he had caused most improperly the same thing to be published in the Richmond Enquirer, he had not been able to prevail upon the Committee to express any such censure. What foundation of Justice therefore was there for the Executive, to inflict upon Mr Edwards the whole punishment that he could if the most pointed vote of censure had been passed upon him, by the Committee?— Nay if he had been convicted upon impeachment, the whole extent of the power of the President, would have been to remove him— And what purpose could that now answer but to give Mr Crawford a triumph, not merely of justification but of revenge?— Mr Wirt said that the course which I proposed would he believed be that which would in after times appear to have been the most just and honourable— But that he could not help being affected by the prevailing popular prejudice—the universal reprobation of Edwards in the public mind—first excited by his apparent running away from his own accusation; and next by the general impression that upon his recent examination he had entirely sunk and lost himself before the Committee; and finally by the testimony of Noble; fixing upon him the solemn denial while his nomination was before the Senate that he was the author of the A B publications which he so shortly afterwards avowed; and a high panegyrick upon Mr Crawford whom he so shortly afterwards accused— These things so affected his moral reputation, that it seemed scarcely possible to send him as a Minister in a foreign Country, without the Government itself’s catching the infection with which his name is tainted— About this stage of the discussion, came in a Letter from Mr Edwards to the President; resigning his Commission, enclosed in a Note, requesting that he would keep it a few days, before filing it in the Department of State, that he might determine, whether he should assign his reasons for his resignation— This immediately changed the topic of deliberation— Mr Wirt said that if there was no sufficient reason
for removing Edwards, there was in his Wirts opinion, no reason for his resigning; and as his resignation had probably been sent in consequence of the Conversations between him, Wirt, and D. P. Cook, if the President’s opinion was that Edwards ought not to be removed, he ought to have the option of withdrawing his resignation— There was then a proposal that Cook should again be seen or written to by Mr Wirt, to warn Edwards to keep the tender of his resignation secret, and that if he pleased he might withdraw it— To this I objected; wishing that no unsteadiness or wavering might appear in the proceedings of the Executive; but I urged that the President should come to a decision, in the Event of Edwards’s withdrawing his Resignation; whether he would revoke the Commission or not— The discussion continued till Calhoun declared that he came over to my opinion, and Wirt said his mind was so divided that he was for both sides of the question— Southard was little less perplexed, and the President finally declined deciding till tomorrow— I then observed that previous to a decision it would be proper to complete the reading of the papers; and they were read— Calhoun, Southard and Wirt all expressed the opinion that Edwards was a deeply injured man; and Calhoun repeatedly said that all his charges against Mr Crawford were made good. They remarked much upon the composition of the Committee, and Calhoun said that one different individual in the place of Webster would have given an entirely a different aspect to the whole affair— Shortly after dinner, and while the papers were reading, the Washington Republican of the Evening was brought in— The resignation of Mr Edwards was announced in it— The reading of the papers was nevertheless completed; and about eight in the Evening, Mr Clark, the Clerk of the House of Representatives came and took them away for publication. About 5. O’Clock I went over to my Office, and looked over the Letters received by the Mail of the day— On returning, I found them at dinner. Mrs Monroe and Mr Hay were at Table— At the same time with this Affair, that of William Rector, Surveyor General in Illinois, Missouri and Arkansas was drawing to a close— The attorney General gave in to the President a Report of 70 pages, against him, upon charges made by David Barton, Senator from Missouri— G. Graham, Commissioner of the Land Office, was at the President’s in the course of the day, upon that subject— The President postponed reading this Report till tomorrow. Among the observations made by the President during the day, he intimated that he should appoint Poinsett to go to Mexico; and that he intended fully to ascertain the real state of the management of the Treasury
Department for the last nine Months— And said that if necessary he should appoint according to Law, a person to act, during Mr Crawford’s intended absence: and should charge me with that trust, if I would undertake it— I said I had no doubt he would find upon examination that the business of the Treasury Department had been transacted with as much accuracy and fidelity as was compatible with Mr Crawford’s indisposition; and if no material inconvenience to the public service had occurred, or was likely to occur, I thought it would be best not to make the temporary appointment— The use of a fac simile of his signature is the only fact of questionable legality and propriety that has been mentioned; the fact itself was said to be established, but I suppose the fac simile has been kept at his own house, and used only by himself, or at his order. There was much comment upon it, by Calhoun, Southard and Wirt; and a speech of Webster’s during the Session, adverting to Mr Crawford’s inability to discharge the duties of his Office, and to the Law applicable to the case, which he read, was noticed— That debate was not reported, or was slurred over in the National Intelligencer, but Wirt said he had heard, Webster’s remarks were supposed to have been intended to attract the attention of the President to the actual state of the Treasury— The range of discussion this day was over the whole history of Mr Monroe’s Administration—and to the deadly opposition against it by Mr Crawford’s partizans from the Seminole war debates down to the Ratification of the Slave-trade Convention. The President said he thought Mr Crawford had not sufficiently discountenanced this warfare; but that he had once shewn him a reply from Cobb, to a Letter from Crawford to him, which indicated that Crawford had disapproved the Trio attack of 1821— I came home this Evening so much exhausted by the labour of the day that I was unable to write.

23. VI:30.Watkins here— Says Lee is anxious that he should enter upon his Office as 4th. Auditor— Will accept in writing— And attend about two hours from 9 to 11. every morning at the Department of State, upon the settlement of the Florida Treaty Claims; as long as may be necessary. Thomas Hartell, brought me a Letter from J. Mower— New-York politics— A. B. Woodward—asked him to call again to-morrow Morning. D. P. Cook, anxious to leave the City to return home— I told him I thought Mr Edwards had acted correctly, in determining to assign his reasons for resigning his Office— And I mention the views that I had taken of the case, so far as they concerned Edwards at the Cabinet Meetings of yesterday and the day before. Cook wished to know whether Rectors case had been decided, and in the event of his removal, wished that his brother, or Judge N. Pope might be appointed in his place. Stackelberg at the Office. Made the arrangement with him for taking his Bill for £1000 Sterling, and sending
it as a remittance to C. Hughes— Hodgson and Wyer at the Office— At the President’s— He said Seaton had been to enquire if it was true that Edwards had resigned— The President spoke of some excitement that he had heard of, at his having been permitted to resign. Mr G. Graham was at the President’s— Resolutions of H.R. relating to the Florida Land-titles. Rector’s affair. P.U.S. gave me the Attorney General’s opinion to read; which I did and sent it back. Evening visit from Richard Peters and John Gray.

24. VI:30.A. B. Woodward— Long Conversation with him, appointment of Governor of Florida— Home Department. Woodward’s conversation about it with Crawford, last Sunday— Crawfords remarks concurred with mine— A. Hamilton’s anonymous Letters to Washington against Jefferson— Resignations of Jefferson, Knox, and Hamilton— John Gray called— Overall for a subscription and a Clerkship— J. S. Barbour with General Rector—who wanted time to take over again a part of the testimony in his case, and a copy of the Attorney General’s opinion. Subscription for the 5th. of July dinnerBarrell; has come to settle in this City. At the President’s— Informed him of Rector’s wish for time— Met Southard on my return to the Office— He is going to morrow for New-Jersey— Conversation— Who Minister to Mexico? Poinsett? recommended in New York National Advocate—why? I told P.U.S— Letters from D. Schnebly and J. H. Pleasants. Opinions on internal improvement— Evening walk with Wyer.

25. VI:30.A. B. Woodward— Long Conversation continued. of E. Randolph. T. Pickering— Hamilton’s admiration of Julius Caesar— J. S. Barbour—to recommend J. P. Duval for judge in Arkansas, in the room of Selden, killed in a duel. H. W. Conway to recommend William Trimble, a brother of David— Rector is removed— Hertell—further talk upon New-York Politics— A Clintonian, sensible and judicious— Jenny, the black woman came to plead again not to be sold to a Georgia trader— One of her sons has this day been sold— I told her to ask Mr T. Cook to call here. D. Barton and D. P. Cook came to take leave— W. Lee with Anderson; from New-York— At the Office— Mr Campbell, who married General Hull’s daughter— Urges Hull’s claim for Salary as Governor of Michigan in 1812. Has been paid as Major General for the same time; but claims both— Alledges Wilkinson for the precedent. Referred him to the Comptroller Anderson— J. P. Van Ness came to see his brother’s Letter, declining the appointment of 4th. Auditor and saw it— J. S. Barbour, again to recommend J. P. Duval as judge in Arkansas— At P.U.S.G. Graham there.
Resolutions of H.R. concerning Florida land titles.— Laws of the legislative Councils— Keepers of the Archives—removable only by the Governor— He to be advised— W. G. D. Worthington to be spoken to— Power of P.U.S. extends no farther— Coll.M’Rae to be surveyor in place of Rector— W. Trimble to be judge in Arkansas— P.U.S. Harrassed with business—goes to Loudoun to morrow— Will come back next Wednesday— Salmon’s complaints— Letters from Commodore Porter, who arrived last Evening from Metanzas— Evening walk with D. P. Cook.— His anticipations of opposition at home— Watkins— His conversation this day with Calhoun— Newspaper Electioneering prospects— Calhoun’s neutrality and his preferences.

26. VI:15.P.U.S. went to Loudoun.— Barton came and introduced a Mr Anderson— J. S. Barbour to ask that J. P. Duval’s name might not be mentioned for the appointment of judge in Arkansas— But it had been mentioned at his request— T. Cook about Jenny— I promised again to make up the deficiency of what she may be sold for, less than 200 dollars, on condition she shall not be sent out of the district against her will. Visit from Genl. Scott, who is in continual motion— At the Office came Addington— Spoke of the S.C. Law, and of the complaint against Porter and Gregory—of the Slave-trade Convention and Brazil. D. P. Cook came and took leave— Going with Barton to-morrow Morning— G. Sullivan; back from Boston, as sole agent for the claim— Received depatches from R. Rush, James Brown, H. Nelson, H. Dearborn, C. Hughes. all untoward— Many private Letters— Solitary evening walk, and wrote to Mrs. Adams— Summer heats, prostrating.

27. V: Swam with John in the Potowmac—to the Bridge—50 minutes. High, Spring tide. Heard Little. Philippians 1:10. “That ye may approve things that are excellent; that ye may be sincere and without offence till the day of Christ.” Balch at Bakers. Colossians 3.2 “Set your affection on things above, not on things on the earth.” and Little Luke 12.15 “And he said unto them, Take heed and beware of covetousness: for a man’s life consisteth not in the abundance of the things which he possesseth.”— Visit from G. Hay— Effect of the Declaration of Independence, to dissolve political corporations. Sentiment in my Address of 4. July. 1821.— Genl. S. Smith of Baltimore— Came upon business this day; to return home to-morrow. Letter from T. Pickering to him. Claims on France, Naples, Denmark and Sweden— N. Edwards in my pew this Evening: came home with me— Has received a Letter proving that the time of his Conversation with Noble, could not have been when Noble states it— Solemnly declares that the whole purport of it has been grossly misrepresented by Noble— Watkins was at my house— Barton & D. P. Cook went off this morning— H. W. Conway last Night challenged Barton to fight, which Barton declined upon the ground of his having made
charges against Conway, in the Affair of Rector, which had been proved to be well-founded, by the removal of Rector— Major Miller who was Conway’s second, refused at first to carry back this answer, but Cook who was Barton’s second, insisted upon it, and it was carried— Miller was to have been Cook’s second, if he had fought with Forsyth, as was expected.

28. VI. Swam in the Potowmack, with John and Antoine—1. hour and twenty minutes in the water— Overtaken by a thunder shower. G. Hay here— Has found in my Address the Sentiment that he expected. Read to him my Letter to J. H. Pleasants— Vallenilla called. I appointed 2. O’Clock to see Salazar— Stackelberg—brought a Note from Count Engeström, about admission of Colonial produce in American Vessels into Sweden— To take leave of P.U.S. on Thursday— Hepburn, with a Letter from R. Rush. Hepburn wishes this Government to apply to that of G.B. for documentary Evidence of a private claim of his against the State of Maryland. I told him it was a private application, to be made by an Agent of his own; Mr Rush might if he wished it be instructed to support it by his influence. Salazar— Two hours conference with him— Colombian Privateering Ordinance— Our objections to several of its Articles— Captures of the Privateer General Santander— Salazar is to see me again— Menou— Expecting the arrival of the Minister, Durant de Mareuil— Menou expects then to go to France, and to be employed elsewhere— Commercial Intercourse, claims of indemnity— Louisiana Treaty 8th. Article claim— Political relations— Difference of Treatment from G.B. and Russia— Nothing to be done, during the remnant of this Administration— Wyer dined with us. walk with him after dinner— Overpowering heat. Thunder shower.

29. V: Morning Thunder Showers— No visitors— Writing to Garnett. At the Office— Joseph Forrest— Florida Treaty Commission papers. Despatch to R. C. Anderson— Solitary walk after dinner. N. Edwards here— His proof against Noble’s testimony— Oppressive heat.

30. V:30. Swam in the Potowmack. 1. hour and 10 minutes— Closing and violent thunder gust, after three days of showers— Several places struck; a child killed— P.U.S. back from Loudoun— At his house with the despatches received. Wyer— Dined at Dr Thornton’s— Boston after dinner.
